text:
Engaging CIOs in a cloud migration
requires a strategic approach

that considers their priorities,
concerns, and goals.

There are four ways to engage
CIOs.

The first is collaborate 
with your CIO peer.

Make sure your cloud strategy
is linked to business objectives

and that you understand
the key assumptions to form

your own opinion on the technical
undertaking.

You should be able to answer
a few questions. Why are we doing
this?
Give them meaning.
How are we going to do it?
Give them confidence.
What does it mean for them?
Show why they should care.

Nearly a quarter of CFOs feel
they either have no effective

collaboration or only limited
collaboration with the CIO when

compared to their other C-suite
peers, per a recent E&Y study.

With millions or billions
of dollars on the line, it is
important to work together.

With that kind of investment
as companies move toward digital

transformation, CFOs can’t
afford not to engage regularly
with their CIOs.

And CIOs have to do all they
can to nurture this essential
strategic relationship.
The next way to engage is to analyze.

You should partner together
to develop the case for change.

CIOs can really benefit from
your analytical, problem
solving mindset.

CFOs have a broad perspective
of the company’s strategy

and the ways in which to monitor
its progress.

Leverage your strength and the
strength of your organization

to help IT leadership
frame out the business case.

Align the investment profile
and the value delivery in the financial
planning process.

Help your CIO hold other C-suite
peers accountable for delivery.

IT cannot be viewed as a “cost”
to the organization,

but rather an “investment”
to drive your business.

The third way to engage is to
measure together.

Being able to articulate
the business value of a cloud

transformation is important
for both the CFO and CIO.

Linking how the technology
drives external outcomes

is not only important for internal
leadership, but also for external
stakeholders.

Traditional operational-level
IT metrics may not meet your

needs, but focusing on business
value will.

You can partner with your CIO
to make that happen.

And the last way to engage
CIOs is to develop a forward-looking
plan.

According to Gartner, 95 percent
of organizations that conduct

long-term planning are more
likely to outperform organizations
that don’t plan ahead.

Having a multi-year view of migration
and modernization cycles will

help both the CFO and CIO to influence
the C-suite on prioritization
and timing.

These four areas will help develop
the foundation of a great partnership

between you, as CFO, and your
CIO to drive digital transformation
for your organization.

on this topic, check out the
links in the description.
Thanks for watching!
